DetailContent.body:
The QRH is intended for use by individuals who are familiar with it and who are practised in its use.

See http://anaesthetists.org/Quick-Reference-Handbook for further details on implementation.
Each guideline follows the same format:
Guideline number, name and version number
A brief description of the clinical situation for which the guideline is written
The body of the guideline with steps
Call out boxes, which may be referred to in the steps
A guideline may suggest changing to one of the other guidelines, like this: (â†’2-1)

Each guideline should be used in the same simple way.

  • Start at START
  • Work through the numbered bullet points in order.
  • Where indicated, refer to the call out boxes on the right.
  • Where indicated, move to another guideline.

We recommend:

  • One person should read the guideline aloud; they should NOT also be the person performing the actions.
  • The reader should ensure that the guideline is followed systematically, thoroughly and completely and that steps are not omitted.
  • Whenever experienced help arrives, consider delegating leadership to them: they have a fresh pair of eyes and may be able to make a more clear-headed assessment.
The original handbook PDF for each section can be downloaded by clicking the button at the top-right of the screen.

DetailContent.head: The guidelines in this handbook are not intended to be standards of medical care. The ultimate judgement with regard to a particular clinical procedure or treatment plan must be made by the clinician in the light of the clinical data presented and the diagnostic and treatment options available.
